::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

@cr-scrollytelling 
  
:::{#cr-scrollytelling .body-text-l style="margin-top: 200px; margin-left: 50px;"}
Have you ever wanted to go beyond the traditional structure of a `.qmd`? Scrollytelling is a powerful data storytelling technique that invites your reader to *walk in the data's shoes* ‚Äî revealing insights step by step as they scroll. The `closeread` Quarto extension makes this easy, giving you flexible, interactive tools to tell your story exactly the way you want. 
:::

:::{.body-text-l style="margin-left: 50px;"}
Let's walk through how to create your own scrollytelling story with `closeread`! 
:::

```{bash}

#| echo: true
quarto add qmd-lab/closeread
```

:::{.body-text-m}  
<br>
Type **"Yes"** when prompted to allow the extension to execute code.
:::

:::

```{bash}
#| echo: true

format:

```

<br>
[**Triggers:**]{.teal-text} The scrolling content ‚Äî text, images, or plots ‚Äî that moves past your stickies and controls what appears on screen.

::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-section-syntax" .body-text-l style="margin-top: 200px; margin-left: 50px;"}
Every closeread document is built from **sections**. Within each section, you specify a layout that controls where your narrative and sticky content appear. There are five layout options to choose from.

[Note: Any content outside a closeread section will appear as regular markdown ‚Äî no scrolling behavior.]{.teal-text}
:::

:::{#cr-section-syntax style="font-size: 28px; padding: 40px;"}
```
::::{.cr-section layout="LAYOUT-NAME"}
Content goes here!
::::
```
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-section-syntax"}
[**sidebar-left**]{.teal-text} (default) 

Narrative scrolls on the left

[**sidebar-right**]{.teal-text} 

Narrative scrolls on the right

[**overlay-left**]{.teal-text} 

Full-screen sticky with floating narrative on the left

[**overlay-center**]{.teal-text} 

Full-screen sticky with centered floating narrative

[**overlay-right**]{.teal-text} 

Full-screen sticky with floating narrative on the right

<br>
[**Choose the layout that best showcases your story!**]{.dark-blue-text .body-text-m}
:::

<!-- SYNTAX: STICKIES & TRIGGERS     -->
<!-- =============================== -->

::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-left"}

:::{focus-on="cr-sticky-syntax"}
[To create a sticky, wrap your element in a fenced div and give it an ID prefixed with `cr-`:]{.body-text-m}
:::

:::{#cr-sticky-syntax .body-text-m style="padding: 40px; margin-top:150px"}
[**Creating a Sticky:**]{.teal-text}

```
:::{#cr-YOUR-ID}
Your content goes here!
(text, image, plot, code, etc.)
:::
```

- Must start with `#cr-`
- ID must be unique
- Can contain any element
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-trigger-syntax"}
[To create a trigger, reference your sticky ID using the `@cr-` syntax. When this text scrolls into view, it will reveal your sticky!]{.body-text-m}
:::

:::{#cr-trigger-syntax .body-text-m style="padding: 40px;"}
[**Creating a Trigger:**]{.teal-text}

```
Your narrative text goes here. @cr-YOUR-ID
```

Or wrap multiple blocks:

```
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-ID"}
Your narrative text goes here.
More text here too!
:::
```

- `@cr-` for single-paragraph triggers
- `focus-on=` for multi-block triggers
:::

<!-- =============================== -->
<!-- FEATURE 1: HIGHLIGHTING         -->
<!-- =============================== -->

::::{.cr-section layout = "sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-hl-section-title" style="height: 30vh;"}
:::

:::{#cr-hl-section-title .body-text-xl .teal-text style="padding: 40px; text-align: center;"}
**Feature 1: Highlighting**
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-hl-code-demo"}
:::{.body-text-m}
The most reliable way to use `highlight=` in closeread is with **code blocks**. The sticky on the left shows an R script ‚Äî scroll to watch specific lines light up!
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-hl-code-demo" highlight="1,2"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`highlight="1,2"`** ‚Äî lines 1 and 2 are highlighted. Here we're loading our packages. You can highlight a single line or multiple lines separated by commas.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-hl-code-demo" highlight="4"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`highlight="4"`** ‚Äî now just line 4. We're pointing to where the data is being loaded.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-hl-code-demo" highlight="6,7,8"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`highlight="6,7,8"`** ‚Äî lines 6 through 8. This is where the ggplot is being built. Highlighting a range of lines is great for walking through logic step by step.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-hl-code-syntax"}
:::{.body-text-m}
Here's how to write this in your `.qmd` file:
:::
:::

:::{#cr-hl-code-demo style="padding: 40px; margin-top: 30px;"}
````r
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

penguins_clean <- na.omit(penguins)

ggplot(penguins_clean, aes(x = bill_length_mm,
                           y = bill_depth_mm,
                           color = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal()
````
:::

:::{#cr-hl-code-syntax .body-text-m style="padding: 40px; border-left: 5px solid #047C90;"}
[**How to write `highlight=` for code blocks:**]{.teal-text}
````
/* highlight= goes on the focus-on block */
/* numbers refer to line numbers in the code block */

/* single line */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" highlight="4"}
Narrative text here.
:::

/* multiple lines (comma-separated) */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" highlight="1,2"}
Narrative text here.
:::

/* range of lines (dash) */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" highlight="4-6"}
Narrative text here.
:::

/* your sticky just needs a regular code block */
:::{#cr-YOUR-STICKY}
```r
library(ggplot2)        ‚Üê line 1
library(palmerpenguins) ‚Üê line 2
```
:::
````

[Note: `highlight=` with line numbers only works on **code block** stickies ‚Äî for prose text, use the span ID approach instead.]{.teal-text}
:::

::::


<!-- =============================== -->
<!-- FEATURE 2: SCALE-BY             -->
<!-- =============================== -->

::::{.cr-section layout = "sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-scale-title" style="height: 30vh;"}
:::

:::{#cr-scale-title .body-text-xl .teal-text style="padding: 40px; text-align: center;"}
**Feature 2: Scaling with `scale-by`**
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo"}
[Default view ‚Äî no transform. The full plot is visible in the sticky.]{.body-text-m}
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo" scale-by="1.5"}
[**`scale-by="1.5"`** ‚Äî zoomed in 50%. The species clusters are easier to compare. Values above 1 zoom in.]{.body-text-m}
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo" scale-by="2.5"}
[**`scale-by="2.5"`** ‚Äî zoomed in 150%. Great for dense plots or small labels.]{.body-text-m}
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo" scale-by="0.7"}
[**`scale-by="0.7"`** ‚Äî zoomed out. Values below 1 shrink the sticky.]{.body-text-m}
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo"}
[Back to default. Each trigger sets its own zoom level independently ‚Äî they don't stack.]{.body-text-m}
:::

[Here's the code that produced this section:]{.body-text-m} @cr-scale-code

:::{#cr-scale-demo style="margin-top: 30px;"}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(
    title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth",
    x = "Bill Length (mm)",
    y = "Bill Depth (mm)",
    color = "Species"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)
```
:::

:::{#cr-scale-code .body-text-m style="padding: 40px; border-left: 5px solid #047C90;"}
[**`scale-by` goes on your `focus-on` trigger:**]{.teal-text}
```
/* Default ‚Äî no transform */
:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo"}
No transform.
:::

/* Zoom in 50% */
:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo" scale-by="1.5"}
Zoomed in!
:::

/* Zoom in 150% */
:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo" scale-by="2.5"}
Even closer!
:::

/* Zoom out */
:::{focus-on="cr-scale-demo" scale-by="0.7"}
Zoomed out.
:::
```
:::

::::


<!-- =============================== -->
<!-- FEATURE 3: PAN-TO               -->
<!-- =============================== -->

::::{.cr-section layout = "sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-title" style="height: 30vh;"}
:::

:::{#cr-pan-title .body-text-xl .teal-text style="padding: 40px; text-align: center;"}
**Feature 3: Panning with `pan-to`**
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-demo"}
:::{.body-text-m}
`pan-to` lets you slide the viewer's focus across a sticky ‚Äî perfect for large images, wide plots, or directing attention to a specific region. Scroll to watch the plot shift!
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-demo" pan-to="25%,0%"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`pan-to="25%,0%"`** ‚Äî panned 25% of its width to the right. Positive percentages shift right (x) and down (y).
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-demo" pan-to="-25%,0%"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`pan-to="-25%,0%"`** ‚Äî panned 25% to the left. Negative values shift left (x) and up (y).
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-demo" pan-to="0%,30%"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`pan-to="0%,30%"`** ‚Äî panned 30% downward. This is great for focusing on axis labels or legends at the bottom of a chart.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-demo" pan-to="25%,-20%" scale-by="1.8"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`pan-to="25%,-20%" scale-by="1.8"`** ‚Äî pan and scale *combined*! Pan shifts the view while scale-by zooms in. Together, they let you spotlight a specific region of any sticky.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-pan-demo"}
:::{.body-text-m}
Back to the default view. Like all focus effects, a trigger with no attributes resets the sticky.
:::
:::

[Here's the code for the combined pan + scale trigger:]{.body-text-m} @cr-pan-code

:::{#cr-pan-demo style="margin-top: 30px;"}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(
    title = "Flipper Length vs. Body Mass",
    x = "Flipper Length (mm)",
    y = "Body Mass (g)",
    color = "Species"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)
```
:::

:::{#cr-pan-code .body-text-m style="padding: 40px; border-left: 5px solid #047C90;"}
[**`pan-to` syntax:**]{.teal-text}
```
/* pan-to takes x,y values in % or px */

/* Pan right */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" pan-to="25%,0%"}
Narrative text.
:::

/* Pan left and up */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" pan-to="-25%,-20%"}
Narrative text.
:::

/* Combine with scale-by for a spotlight effect */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" pan-to="25%,-20%" scale-by="1.8"}
Zoomed in and shifted!
:::

/* Using pixel values instead of percentages */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" pan-to="100px,-50px"}
Shifted by exact pixels.
:::
```

[Tip: `pan-to` works especially well with images and large plots where you want to guide the reader's eye to a specific area.]{.teal-text}
:::

::::


<!-- =============================== -->
<!-- FEATURE 4: ZOOM-TO              -->
<!-- =============================== -->

::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-zoom-title" style="height: 30vh;"}
:::

:::{#cr-zoom-title .body-text-xl .teal-text style="padding: 40px; text-align: center;"}
**Feature 4: Zooming with `zoom-to`**
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-zoom-demo"}
:::{.body-text-m}
`zoom-to` combines panning and scaling into one attribute ‚Äî it automatically pans *and* zooms to a specific line of code or a named span. This is perfect for code walkthroughs!
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-zoom-demo" zoom-to="1"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`zoom-to="1"`** ‚Äî zoomed into line 1. The view pans and scales so this line fills most of the viewport.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-zoom-demo" zoom-to="12"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`zoom-to="12"`** ‚Äî jumped straight to line 12. Unlike manually combining `pan-to` and `scale-by`, `zoom-to` handles both automatically.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-zoom-demo" zoom-to="20"}
:::{.body-text-m}
**`zoom-to="20"`** ‚Äî now focused on line 20. Notice how it pans vertically *and* scales in one smooth motion.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-zoom-demo" hlz = "4"}
:::{.body-text-m}
You can also use `hlz` ("highlight + zoom") to highlight a line while zooming to it ‚Äî the best of both worlds!
:::
:::

[Here's the syntax:]{.body-text-m} @cr-zoom-code

:::{#cr-zoom-demo style="padding: 40px; margin-top: 30px;"}
````r
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

penguins_clean <- na.omit(penguins)

ggplot(penguins_clean, aes(x = bill_length_mm,
                           y = bill_depth_mm,
                           color = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal()
  
penguins_clean <- na.omit(penguins)

ggplot(penguins_clean, aes(x = bill_length_mm,
                           y = bill_depth_mm,
                           color = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal()
  
penguins_clean <- na.omit(penguins)

ggplot(penguins_clean, aes(x = bill_length_mm,
                           y = bill_depth_mm,
                           color = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal()
````
:::

:::{#cr-zoom-code .body-text-m style="padding: 40px; border-left: 5px solid #047C90;"}
[**`zoom-to` and `hlz` syntax:**]{.teal-text}
```
/* zoom-to a specific line number */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" zoom-to="4"}
Zoomed to line 4!
:::

/* zoom-to a named span (for line blocks) */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" zoom-to="cr-my-span"}
Zoomed to the span!
:::

/* hlz = highlight + zoom in one attribute */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" hlz="4"}
Line 4 is highlighted AND zoomed!
:::

/* hlz with a named span */
:::{focus-on="cr-YOUR-STICKY" hlz="cr-my-span"}
Span is highlighted AND zoomed!
:::
```

[Note: `zoom-to` overrides `pan-to` and `scale-by` if they're on the same trigger, since it handles both. Use `hlz` when you want zoom + highlight together.]{.teal-text}
:::

**Feature 5: Custom Styling with SCSS**

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-what-title" style="height: 30vh;"}
:::

:::{#cr-scss-what-title .body-text-xl .dark-blue-text style="padding: 40px; text-align: center;"}
**What Can You Customize?**
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-overview"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
Closeread works seamlessly with SCSS, giving you control over four major areas. Scroll to see each one!
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-overview" highlight="1,2"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
[**Background**]{.teal-text} ‚Äî the canvas behind everything. Set a background color or image for your closeread sections.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-overview" highlight="4,5"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
[**Sticky Elements**]{.teal-text} ‚Äî the container holding your stickies. Control background color, padding, borders, and shadows.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-overview" highlight="7,8"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
[**Narrative Elements**]{.teal-text} ‚Äî the scrolling text column. Adjust background, padding, and width.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-overview" highlight="10,11,12"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
[**Fonts**]{.teal-text} ‚Äî size, family, and color. Define reusable utility classes you can apply anywhere in your `.qmd`.
:::
:::

:::{#cr-scss-overview style="padding: 40px; margin-top: 30px;"}
````scss
/* 1. Background */
.cr-section { background-color: ...; }

/* 2. Sticky element */
.sticky-col-stack { ... }

/* 3. Narrative element */
.narrative-col { ... }

/* 4. Fonts */
font-family: ...;
font-size: ...;
color: ...;
````
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-how-title" style="height: 30vh;"}

:::{#cr-scss-how-title .body-text-xl .dark-blue-text style="padding: 40px; text-align: center;"}
**How To Customize: Writing Your SCSS**
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-setup-how"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
Before writing any styles, you need two things: a `.scss` file and a link to it in your YAML front matter. Scroll to see both!
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-setup-how" highlight="1,2,3,4,5,6,7"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
[**Step 1 ‚Äî Your YAML:**]{.teal-text} Add a `theme` key under `closeread-html` that points to your SCSS file. Make sure it's in the same directory as your `.qmd`.
:::
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-scss-setup-how" highlight="9,10,11"}
:::{.body-text-m style="margin-left: 50px;"}
[**Step 2 ‚Äî Your SCSS file:**]{.teal-text} Create `closeread-styles.scss` in that same project directory. Standard SCSS syntax ‚Äî no special closeread magic required.
:::
:::

:::{#cr-scss-setup-how style="padding: 40px; margin-top: 30px;"}
````yaml
---
title: "My Closeread Story"
format:
  closeread-html:
    theme:
      - closeread-styles.scss
---
````

````scss
/* closeread-styles.scss */
/* Your custom styles go here! */
````
:::

::::


::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

[Now let's look at each style category. On the left is the code for **background**, **stickies**, **narrative**, and **fonts** all in one file. Scroll through to see each block!]{.body-text-m} @cr-full-scss

[**Background** targets `.cr-section`. Use `background-color` for a solid fill or `background-image` for a photo. Set `color` here too so your text stays readable.]{.body-text-m} @cr-full-scss

[**Sticky elements** target `.sticky-col-stack` ‚Äî the container wrapping your `:::{#cr-YOUR-ID}` content. Round the corners, add a shadow, give it a background ‚Äî whatever fits your story.]{.body-text-m} @cr-full-scss

[**Narrative elements** target `.narrative-col` ‚Äî the scrolling text column. A semi-transparent `rgba` background works especially well with `overlay-*` layouts, where narrative floats over a full-screen sticky.]{.body-text-m} @cr-full-scss

[**Fonts** ‚Äî import a Google Font at the top, set `font-family` on `body`, then define reusable utility classes like `.teal-text` or `.body-text-xl`. These are the exact classes used throughout this document!]{.body-text-m} @cr-full-scss

:::{#cr-full-scss .body-text-m style="padding: 40px; border-left: 5px solid #047C90; margin-top: 30px;"}
[**Your complete `closeread-styles.scss`:**]{.teal-text}
````scss
/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Google Fonts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
@import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?
  family=Lato:wght@400;700&display=swap');

/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Base Body ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
body {
  font-family: 'Lato', sans-serif;
  line-height: 1.65;
}

/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Section Background ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
.cr-section {
  background-color: #f4f1ec;
  background-image: url("your-image.jpg");
  background-size: cover;
  color: #1a1a2e;
}

/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Sticky Container ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
.sticky-col-stack {
  background-color: #ffffff;
  border-radius: 8px;
  padding: 2rem;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 16px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
  border: 1px solid #e0e0e0;
}

/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Narrative Column ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
.narrative-col {
  background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.85);
  padding: 1.5rem 2rem;
  border-radius: 8px;
  max-width: 480px;
}

/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Font Size Utilities ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
.body-text-xl { font-size: 2rem; }
.body-text-l  { font-size: 1.5rem; }
.body-text-m  { font-size: 1.15rem; }
.body-text-s  { font-size: 0.9rem; }

/* ‚îÄ‚îÄ Color Utilities ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ */
.teal-text      { color: #047C90; }
.dark-blue-text { color: #1a1a2e; }
.white-text     { color: #ffffff; }
````
:::
